title: Kakavia (soup)
text:
Kakavia () is a <a href="Greek%20cuisine">Greek</a> fish soup. 
Its name comes from the "kakavi", the <a href="tripod">tripod</a> <a href="Cookware%20and%20bakeware">cooking pot</a> used by ancient <a href="Ionians">Ionian</a> fishermen. Kakavia has been described as "the most ancient of Greek fish soups", and related to lineage to the French <a href="bouillabaisse">bouillabaisse</a>; like that stew, kakavia is made with a flexible variety of fish and is associated with <a href="fishing%20village">fishing village</a>s.
It was traditionally made from the smallest fish caught by fishermen, along with <a href="olive%20oil">olive oil</a>, <a href="onion">onion</a>s, and <a href="saffron">saffron</a>.
One modern recipe calls for <a href="Fillet%20%28cut%29">fillet</a>ed and chunked <a href="Whitefish%20%28fisheries%20term%29">whitefish</a> (such as <a href="cod">cod</a>, <a href="Atlantic%20goliath%20grouper">goliath grouper</a>, or <a href="Lutjanidae">snapper</a>), <a href="prawn">prawn</a>s, fish or vegetable <a href="Stock%20%28food%29">stock</a>, <a href="tomato">tomato</a>es, <a href="onion">onion</a>s, <a href="potato">potato</a>es, <a href="olive%20oil">olive oil</a>, <a href="lemon%20juice">lemon juice</a>, and a <a href="Garnish%20%28food%29">garnish</a> of flatleaf (Italian) <a href="parsley">parsley</a>. Another calls for three or four kinds of fish cleaned and sliced for <a href="Poaching%20%28cooking%29">poaching</a> (<a href="Bass%20%28fish%29">bass</a>, cod, <a href="wikt%3Ahake">hake</a>, <a href="haddock">haddock</a>, <a href="halibut">halibut</a>, <a href="trout">trout</a>, <a href="pollock">pollock</a>, snapper, <a href="wikt%3Arockfish">rockfish</a>, <a href="Merlangius%20merlangus">whiting</a>), plus <a href="shrimp">shrimp</a> and perhaps <a href="lobster">lobster</a> or <a href="scallop">scallop</a>s, along with onions, <a href="scallion">scallion</a>s, or <a href="leek">leek</a>s; olive oil; tomato; stalk <a href="fennel">fennel</a> or <a href="celery">celery</a>; fresh parsley; fresh <a href="thyme">thyme</a>; <a href="bay%20leaf">bay leaf</a>; ground <a href="black%20pepper">black pepper</a>; <a href="white%20wine">white wine</a> and water; and toasted <a href="crouton">crouton</a>s.
Kakavia is similar to other types of Mediterranean fish stew, such as the French <a href="bouillabaisse">bouillabaisse</a>, Italian <a href="cacciucco">cacciucco</a>, Spanish zarzuela, and Portuguese <a href="caldeirada">caldeirada</a>.
